text: the national hi violet hi everyone
Anthony Fantino here thanks for watching
Internet's busiest music nerd doing an
album review the Nationals hi violet the
National is a Brooklyn band they've been
together for about 10 years now and
they've just put out their fifth album
and the National has a distinctly cool
and reserved rock sound and what's
awesome about this album is that it was
recorded in my home state of Connecticut
in the same studio where they recorded
turn on the bright lights by Interpol
but but but but that's enough fanboy ISM
if you're gonna expect anything of this
LP if you're going to expect anything of
hi violet make sure you're ready for
some white collar blues filtered through
a very bleak mournful post-punk sound
this is the kind of self-perpetuating
sadness that occurs when you're making
$80,000 a year but yet you still believe
that something's just still not right
about your life as you look down on the
busy city streets from your high-rise
New York studio apartment so if that's
something you have difficulty relating
to the sentiments of hi violet might not
exactly resonate in your heart of hearts
but for the most part of half-joking
there is something arguably relatable
about The Melancholy sounds of this
album and the Nationals music in general
whether it's the good production the
great songwriting or matt baron injures
baritone vocals there's a lot to like
and i'm seriously a sucker for baritone
vocals it's not really a fan of these
thin whiny pansy vocals go through and
though hi violet is a sad LP there are a
lot of aspects to it that make it a
really easy pill to swallow and I think
the strongest of those aspects is the
production the horns the strings there's
even a point where I think I hear oboe
just the
lot of color a lot of texture throughout
this whole LP and I think the best
addition to this album is most
definitely the mechanical meticulous
drumming style usually I like my drums a
little more dynamic a little more
interactive maybe with a little more
variation but I wouldn't have it any
other way on this album because if the
drums weren't so sharp and just right on
tempo this album would seriously sound
like a bowl of sambar mush and now that
I've touched down on that point there
are actually some parts of this LP that
do sound like that just a bowl of somber
mush so much gray area that you'll just
be begging for some black and white to
just make things a little more lively
tracks that are so weighted down in
misery and instrumentation that I think
they actually try to sonically drown
themselves out in some kind of music
related suicide attempt the tracks that
I actually found myself loving loving to
death weren't the simplest or more
straightforward tracks but the ones
where you could actually hear a decent
separation between each of the
instruments I'm thinking conversation 16
I'm thinking blood buzz Ohio anyone's
ghost sorrow these are really beautiful
well-crafted songs with in extreme
attention to detail like Eleanor Rigby
take a note out it's ruined there really
is a strong assembly of very cinematic
tracks on this album that when I hear
them even though I'm not digging every
single song on high violet
it really makes me think damn the
National is completely deserving of
every shred of fame that they receive hi
violet for me does have its share of
great moments but there is this handful
of tracks that are just keeping me from
falling in love with this album and I
don't know if that's the general
consensus because a majority of the
reviews that I'm seeing for this thing
are just fiercely fiercely positive this
thing most definitely has some nice
sound some decent songs to spare and a
lot of attention to detail but I think
its biggest downfall is maybe it's
consist
see because if you set back from this
album even just a few feet everything
tends to get very very blurry as if this
thing is almost too cohesive for its own
good because after just experiencing
this ongoing sad somber emotion in one
sitting kind of makes it difficult for
me to just muster up the strength and
the attention span to listen to even the
last two tracks which arguably have some
of the best production on the entire
album though I did enjoy this LP for the
most part just too many songs fell into
the gray area for me and if you feel the
same way maybe because of these stronger
tracks on the album like blood buzz Ohio
it's kind of worth it to stick around
and maybe acclimate yourself to those
weaker or less immediate tracks I'm
feeling a strong six on this album but
what do you guys think I know this thing
is getting a ton ton of good reviews and
are you one of the people who thinks
this album is amazing and if so tell me
why down there in the comment box and
also how do you think this album
compares to their earlier work
Anthony Fantana the National High Violet
forever
